First Meeting 28 December 2025 6 min read

Preparing for Your First Behaviour Support Meeting

First MeetingPreparationWhat to Expect

Before the Meeting

Preparation is key to making the most of your initial consultation with a behaviour support practitioner. Here are some steps to help you prepare:

Gather Relevant Information

Collect and organize the following documents:

  • Current NDIS plan and goals
  • Any existing behaviour support documentation
  • Recent incident reports or support notes (if applicable)
  • Contact details for key support people
  • Relevant medical or psychological reports

Think About Your Goals

Consider what you hope to achieve through behaviour support. What would success look like for you or your loved one? Think about:

  • What behaviours are causing concern?
  • When and where do these behaviours occur?
  • What have you already tried?
  • What outcomes are you hoping for?

During the Meeting

What to Expect

Your initial consultation will typically include:

  • Discussion of current situation and challenges
  • Review of any existing documentation
  • Explanation of the behaviour support process
  • Discussion of supervision arrangements (if applicable)
  • Outline of next steps and timeline
  • Opportunity for you to ask questions

Questions to Ask

Prepare a list of questions, such as:

  • What does the assessment process involve?
  • How long does the process typically take?
  • What are the costs involved?
  • How will we measure progress?
  • What is your availability and service area?
  • How does supervision work (if applicable)?
  • What will be expected of me and my support team?

Share Your Story

Be prepared to share information about:

  • What a typical day looks like
  • Successful strategies you've used
  • Challenges you face regularly
  • What's most important to you

Who Should Attend

Consider who should be present at the meeting:

  • The NDIS participant (if appropriate)
  • Family members or guardians
  • Key support workers
  • Service coordinator (if applicable)

After the Meeting

Take time to reflect on the discussion and whether you feel comfortable with the practitioner's approach. Consider:

  • Did they listen to your concerns?
  • Did they explain things clearly?
  • Do you feel comfortable with their approach?
  • Do their suggestions make sense to you?

Don't Hesitate to Ask Questions

Remember, this is your opportunity to ensure you're making the right choice. Don't hesitate to ask follow-up questions or request clarification on anything you're unsure about. A good practitioner will welcome your questions and be happy to explain their approach.

About the Author
